claim: The monad is the fundamental simple substance that has no parts
text: The monad is the fundamental simple substance that has no parts
quote: The monad is simple. it has no parts.

claim: Composite substances require simple substances as their constituents
text: Composite substances require simple substances as their constituents
quote: There must simple substances, since composite ones consist of them.

claim: Simple substances have no extension or shape and are the true atoms of nature
text: Simple substances have no extension or shape and are the true atoms of nature
quote: What is simple has no extension and therefore no shape. Monads are the true atoms of nature.

claim: Monads cannot be destroyed because destruction requires taking apart parts
text: Monads cannot be destroyed because destruction requires taking apart parts
quote: Monads cannot be destroyed, since to destroy is to take apart and monads have no parts.

claim: Monads cannot be created by composition for the same reason they cannot be destroyed
text: Monads cannot be created by composition for the same reason they cannot be destroyed
quote: For the same reason mutatis mutandis, monads cannot be created.

claim: Monads come into and depart from existence instantaneously through annihilation or ex nihilo creation
text: Monads come into and depart from existence instantaneously through annihilation or ex nihilo creation
quote: Therefore, monads come into, and depart from, existence instantaneously; they can be destroyed only be being annihilated, not decomposed, and they come into existence ex nihilo, and not in the gradual manner of composites.

claim: Monads cannot undergo internal change and nothing can change them
text: Monads cannot undergo internal change and nothing can change them
quote: It follows that monads cannot undergo internal change. Internal change requires internal parts, and monads have no parts. It also follows that nothing can change a monad. To be changed is for one's internal parts to be rearranged, and monads have no such parts.

claim: Monads have qualities despite lacking parts and must differ qualitatively
text: Monads have qualities despite lacking parts and must differ qualitatively
quote: Even though monads don't have parts, they do have qualities. Monads do not differ in respect of size from one another, as there are no quantitative differences between any two monads. So if there are any such differences, they must be qualitative.

claim: Monads cannot be qualitatively identical because this would make change impossible
text: Monads cannot be qualitatively identical because this would make change impossible
quote: But monads cannot possibly be qualitatively identical. Given that there is no empty space, it follows that each point in space is occupied by a monad and that change involves monads switching places. But if monads are all the same, then the state of the universe before two monads switch places is just like the state of the universe after they do so. Wherefore, unless monads differ in quality, there is no such thing as change.

claim: No two monads are the same because no two objects are the same and differences are rooted in natures
text: No two monads are the same because no two objects are the same and differences are rooted in natures
quote: It follows that some monads are different from some monads. But a stronger claim is warranted, namely, no two monads are the same. This is because no two objects are the same. And the differences between any two objects are rooted in the natures of those objects. It is not simply that those objects differ in respect of their relations to other objects. It is that those two objects have different natures.

claim: Every created being can change and monads are always changing
text: Every created being can change and monads are always changing
quote: Every created being can change. Therefore, monads can change. In fact, monads are always changing.

claim: Changes in monads come from within because nothing external can affect them
text: Changes in monads come from within because nothing external can affect them
quote: These changes come from within. This is because nothing can affect a monad, as we saw in proposition 7.

claim: Each monad must change in its own unique way
text: Each monad must change in its own unique way
quote: And each monad must change in its own way. This is a consequence of the fact that each monad is unique.

claim: Monads are qualitatively internally differentiated and change continuously in some respects
text: Monads are qualitatively internally differentiated and change continuously in some respects
quote: It follows that even though monads do not consist of parts, there is a respect in which they are internally differentiated. They are qualitatively internally differentiated. And when a given monad changes, it must do so in some respects, and not others, since total change would be tantamount to annihilated, and it must do so continuously, since all changes are continuous.

claim: Perception is change-within-unity in a monad, distinct from thought or consciousness
text: Perception is change-within-unity in a monad, distinct from thought or consciousness
quote: Thus, when a monad changes, the change is internal to a being that remains fundamentally unified. Such changes-within-unity are nothing other than we call perception. Perception is not the same thing as thought. Nor is it the same thing as consciousness.

claim: Cartesians wrongly identify consciousness with mind and deny unconscious mental content
text: Cartesians wrongly identify consciousness with mind and deny unconscious mental content
quote: Cartesians hold that consciousness and mind are the same thing, and they deny that there is anything in one's mind of which one is not conscious. For this reason, they wrongly hold that mind and body are distinct and that the soul can perish.

claim: Appetition is the force that drives internal changes in monads
text: Appetition is the force that drives internal changes in monads
quote: The force that drives a monad's internal changes may be referred to as appetition. Any given change in a monad begins with one perception and strives towards a different perception. The target-perception is never reached, but a perception approximating to it is reached, and new perceptions are generated in the course of this transition.

claim: We are simple substances but can perceive complexity because we are internally differentiated
text: We are simple substances but can perceive complexity because we are internally differentiated
quote: The soul is simple. Therefore, we are simple substances. And we find that the object of even the simplest of our perceptions is internally differentiated. It follows that we are internally differentiated, since we could not be aware complexity without ourselves being complex.

claim: Perception cannot be explained mechanically because machines cannot create perceptions
text: Perception cannot be explained mechanically because machines cannot create perceptions
quote: Perception cannot be explained mechanically. Suppose that some machine could create perceptions. That machine could be expanded, so that we could walk around inside it. If we did so, we would see cogs and levers and pulleys; we would see various interacting objects, as in a factory. But we certainly we would not see perceptions or thoughts or feelings. Interacting objects do not create perceptions. Therefore, multiplicities of objects do not have perceptions. Therefore, perceptions are had by simple beings.

claim: An entelechy is a self-powering being, which souls and monads are
text: An entelechy is a self-powering being, which souls and monads are
quote: An entelechy is a self-powering being. Souls are entelechies, and so therefore are monads.

claim: Minds exist where there is perception; souls exist where perception is accompanied by memory
text: Minds exist where there is perception; souls exist where perception is accompanied by memory
quote: We must distinguish between minds and souls. Where there is perception, there is a mind. But it is only where perception is accompanied by memory that there is a soul.

claim: Mere monads are beings with perception but without memory
text: Mere monads are beings with perception but without memory
quote: Henceforth, I refer to mere monads, I am referring to beings that have perception but not memory.

claim: Our condition in dreamless sleep is like that of a mere monad but different because we wake up
text: Our condition in dreamless sleep is like that of a mere monad but different because we wake up
quote: When we are in a dreamless sleep, our condition is more like that of a mere monad than it is otherwise. But we wake up from even the deepest sleep, showing that our condition is different from that of a mere monad even when we are in the depths of the deepest sleep.

claim: Monads have perceptions but they are weak and confused
text: Monads have perceptions but they are weak and confused
quote: But it does not follow that monads have no perceptions. They obviously do. What follows is that their perceptions are weak and confused, as we are during a dizzy spell or period of delirium.

claim: A monad's present condition determines its future condition
text: A monad's present condition determines its future condition
quote: A monad's condition at any given moment is a consequence of its earlier condition. It follows that a monad's future condition is implicit in its present condition.

claim: Unconscious perceptions must exist because we remember confused states
text: Unconscious perceptions must exist because we remember confused states
quote: When you recover from a dizzy spell, you remember what it was like. You therefore must have been taking a mental note of your condition, even though you were not aware of doing so while you were in your delirium. It follows that you were having these perceptions unconsciously. Also, perceptions must arise from other perceptions, just as motions must be caused by other motions, and it follows that conscious perceptions are unconscious perceptions that have become conscious.

claim: Mental lucidity depends on the articulation and accenting of perceptions
text: Mental lucidity depends on the articulation and accenting of perceptions
quote: When we are lucid, it is because our mental state is appropriately articulated, some of our perceptions being more intense, or otherwise more accented, than others. And when we are in a stupor, it is because our perceptions are not thus distinguished from one another. Mental haziness is identical with this absence of internal psychological structure.

claim: Animal sensory abilities depend on bodily organization of stimuli
text: Animal sensory abilities depend on bodily organization of stimuli
quote: Animals often have enormous powerful sensory modalities. The reason an eagle sees so well is that its eyes do such a good job of organize the light rays that strike, and the reason a bat hears so well is that its ears do such a good job of organizing the undulations that affect it. Whenever a creature is possessed of a given sensory modality, it is because his body is structured in a very particular way.

claim: Memory and reason enable creatures to be changed by experience
text: Memory and reason enable creatures to be changed by experience
quote: If a creature has neither memory nor reason, experiences do not change it. If it has either memory or reason, experiences do change it. And in some cases, memory-based changes mimic reason-based changes.

claim: A dog's conditioned behavior is memory-based and reflexive, not rational
text: A dog's conditioned behavior is memory-based and reflexive, not rational
quote: A dog that has been beaten enough times will cringe at the mere sight of the stick used to beat it. The dog's behavior is similar to that of a person who deduces that he is in danger. But the dog's behavior is reflexive, being purely memory-based, and does not embody any actual thought.

claim: Multiple mild perceptions can have the same effect as few intense ones
text: Multiple mild perceptions can have the same effect as few intense ones
quote: A dog that has suffered a few severe beatings may cringe when it sees its master's stick, and so may a dog that has suffered many mild beatings. Sometimes a long series of mild perceptions has the same effect as a few intense ones.

claim: Most human beliefs are based on experience rather than rational inference
text: Most human beliefs are based on experience rather than rational inference
quote: Most of our beliefs are based solely on past experience, there being no element of rational inference. We believe that the sun will rise because experience has conditioned us to believe it. Only the astronomer believes it on the basis of reason.

claim: Humans are distinguished from animals by awareness of necessary truths and logical dependence
text: Humans are distinguished from animals by awareness of necessary truths and logical dependence
quote: What distinguishes us from animals is that we are aware of necessary truths. Unlike animals, we grasp the concept of logical dependence, and this is what makes us rational. Because we are rational, we think about the world in a scientific manner. Because we are rational, we are able to think about ourselves and about God.

claim: Grasping necessary truths enables self-reflection and the concept of God
text: Grasping necessary truths enables self-reflection and the concept of God
quote: It is because we grasp necessary truths that we can think about ourselves. And because we can think about ourselves, we can think about simples, composites, mind, and matter. We thereby learn that what limits one being may not limit another. On this basis, we learn that what limits us need not limit some other being. On this basis, we learn that what limits any finite being need not limit some other being. And on this basis, we grasp the concept of God, that is, of an unlimited being.

claim: All reasoning is based on the Principle of Non-contradiction
text: All reasoning is based on the Principle of Non-contradiction
quote: All reasoning is based on two principles. First, the Principle of Non-contradition. Self-contradictory statements are always false, and the negation of such a statement is always true.

claim: All reasoning is based on the Principle of Sufficient Reason
text: All reasoning is based on the Principle of Sufficient Reason
quote: Second, the Principle of Sufficient Reason. No statement can be true, no fact can exist, unless there is an adequate reason. In most cases, we do not know the reason.

claim: There are two kinds of truths: Truths of Reason and Truths of Fact
text: There are two kinds of truths: Truths of Reason and Truths of Fact
quote: Also, there are two kinds of truths: Truths of Reason and Truths of Fact. Truths of reason are necessary, and their negations cannot possibly be true. Truths of fact are contingent, and their negations can be true.

claim: Necessary truths can be understood through analysis into simple constituents
text: Necessary truths can be understood through analysis into simple constituents
quote: When a truth is necessary, we can learn why it is true by analyzing it. Analyzing a statement involves decomposing it into its simple constitutents.

claim: Mathematical derivation from axioms exemplifies analysis of necessary truths
text: Mathematical derivation from axioms exemplifies analysis of necessary truths
quote: This is what a mathematician is doing when he derives a truth of mathematics from a body of axioms.

claim: Analysis terminates in basic principles whose negations are explicitly self-contradictory
text: Analysis terminates in basic principles whose negations are explicitly self-contradictory
quote: Analysis reaches an end with these basic principles---these axioms, as it were---and the mark of a basic principle is that its negation is explicitly self-contradictory. These basic principles are always identities, that is, truths of the form x=x.

claim: Contingent truths also have sufficient reasons though we may not know them
text: Contingent truths also have sufficient reasons though we may not know them
quote: Mathematicians give reasons for necessary truths. But there are sufficient reasons for contingent truths, as well.

claim: Present behavior results from infinitely complex chains of past events and mental states
text: Present behavior results from infinitely complex chains of past events and mental states
quote: Consider the movements I am now making with my pen. These movements are the end-result of an infinitely long chain of events, and any given link in that chain is of infinite internal complexity. Moreover, innumerably many past mental states of mine are responsible for my having the motivation to make these markings.

claim: Contingent chains of events require looking outside contingencies for sufficient reason
text: Contingent chains of events require looking outside contingencies for sufficient reason
quote: But each of these various antecedents of my behavior leads simply to more antecedents, and each of the internal nuances of any such antecedent refers us simply to more internal structure. No matter how far back in time we follow this chain of events, and no matter how intensively we scrutinize any given one of its links, we fail to encounter a sufficient reason for my behavior. To find such a reason, we must look outside this sequence of contingencies.

claim: God is the necessary being sufficient for all contingencies
text: God is the necessary being sufficient for all contingencies
quote: This necessary being is sufficient for all of these contingencies, which are all interconnected. So there is one God and this God is sufficient.

claim: God's existence is universally implicated and necessary
text: God's existence is universally implicated and necessary
quote: There is nothing distinct from this being that does not depend for its existence on it. Therefore, this being is, quite literally, universally, in that its existence is implicated in that of every aspect of everything in the universe. Moreover, this being cannot be possible without being actual. Therefore, its existence is necessary.

claim: God is unlimited because limitation would compromise sufficiency
text: God is unlimited because limitation would compromise sufficiency
quote: If this being were limited in any way, it would not be sufficient. But it is sufficient, so it is not limited, and it is therefore unlimited in respect of how much reality is in it.

claim: God is responsible for perfections while creatures are responsible for their own imperfections
text: God is responsible for perfections while creatures are responsible for their own imperfections
quote: It follows that God is responsible for each creature's perfections. It also follows that each creature is itself responsible for its own imperfections. A creature's imperfections are what limit it, and what limits it is what distinguishes it from God.

claim: God is the source of both actualities and possibilities, grounding essences in His mind
text: God is the source of both actualities and possibilities, grounding essences in His mind
quote: It also follows that God is the source not only of what is actual, but of what is possible, and that he is therefore responsible for the existence of essences. For it is in God's mind, and nowhere else, that possibilities exist, and without God there would be no possibilities, and therefore no actualities either.

claim: Possibilities must be grounded in actualities and therefore in necessary being
text: Possibilities must be grounded in actualities and therefore in necessary being
quote: This is because possibilities do not exist unless grounded in actualities and must therefore grounded in necessary and eternal truths and, therefore, in a being whose essence involves existence. It follows that God's being possible is sufficient for His being actual.

claim: Only of God can it be said that He must exist if He can exist
text: Only of God can it be said that He must exist if He can exist
quote: Of God and God alone can it be said that He must exist if He can exist. God is unlimited and his existence is in no way negated. Nothing contradicts his existence and it therefore does not self-contradict. Since what is not self-contradictory is possible, God is possible and, since possible, existent. Here, then, is a second proof of God's existence.

claim: Against Descartes: God's will affects contingent truths, His intellect constitutes necessary truths
text: Against Descartes: God's will affects contingent truths, His intellect constitutes necessary truths
quote: According to Descartes, necessary truths depend on God's will and are therefore arbitrary. This is a mistake. God's will is responsible for contingent truths. God's intellect is responsible for necessary truths. Such truths constitute His intellect.

claim: God is the ultimate simple substance who creates all other monads
text: God is the ultimate simple substance who creates all other monads
quote: Thus, God is the ultimate simple substance. All other monads are His creations. They are continuously created by the silent flashes of lightning that God gives off. Finite beings are affected by these flashes of lightning and to that extent, and only to that are they limited.

claim: Divine attributes correspond to monad faculties but only God has them unlimitedly
text: Divine attributes correspond to monad faculties but only God has them unlimitedly
quote: In God, there is *Power, which is the source of everything, *Knowledge, which contains every truth, and *Will, which produces changes, as God sees fit. These correspond, respectively, to *The monad's basic nature, *The monad's perceptual faculty, and *The monad's appetitive faculty. Some derived monads have these attributes to a higher degree than others, but all such monads have them a finite degree. Only God has them to an unlimited degree.

claim: A being's perfection corresponds to its activity and clear perceptions
text: A being's perfection corresponds to its activity and clear perceptions
quote: A being is perfect so far as it acts and imperfect so far as it is acted on. For reasons that I will now explain, it follows that a monad acts in so far as it has clear perceptions and is acted on in so far as it has confused ones.

claim: Clear perceptions enable one monad to be responsible for another's states
text: Clear perceptions enable one monad to be responsible for another's states
quote: To the extent that one monad has clear perceptions and another confused ones, the states of the former can be responsible for those of the latter and the states of the latter cannot be responsible for those of the former. And one created being is more perfect than another to the extent that what happens in it can be said a priori to be responsible for what happens in the second, this being what it means to say that the first 'acts on' the second and the second is 'acted on' by the first.

claim: No monad directly acts on any other; God pre-arranges apparent causal relations
text: No monad directly acts on any other; God pre-arranges apparent causal relations
quote: No monad directly acts on any other. But God so arranges things that the conditions of lesser monads can be inferred from those of higher monads but not vice versa, wherefore God so pre-arranges things that this inferential asymmetry between higher and lesser monads is made to appear as a causal asymmetry between them.

claim: Causal interaction is really explainability in terms of perception clarity
text: Causal interaction is really explainability in terms of perception clarity
quote: For x to act on y, as it were, is for y's condition to be explained in terms of x's, and it is therefore for y's perceptions to lower resolution than, but otherwise comparable to, x's perceptions. If x and y affect each other, that is because x is superior to y in some respects and inferior to y in others, and God so pre-arranged their interactions as to reflect that fact.

claim: God must have had a reason for choosing this universe among infinite possibilities
text: God must have had a reason for choosing this universe among infinite possibilities
quote: Since there are infinitely many possible universes and only one actual one, God must have had a reason for choosing this universe to create.

claim: Only if one universe is better than another is it more worthy of creation
text: Only if one universe is better than another is it more worthy of creation
quote: It is only if one universe is better than another that it is more worthy of being created.

claim: This is the best of all possible worlds
text: This is the best of all possible worlds
quote: Since ours is the only universe that God created, it follows that it is better than every other possible universe. This is the best of all worlds.

claim: Each monad is a mirror of the universe reflecting its intrinsic properties
text: Each monad is a mirror of the universe reflecting its intrinsic properties
quote: Given that the relations of monads are pre-arranged in such as a way as to reflect the differences between them, it follows that a monad's relational properties can be read off of its intrinsic properties. Equivalently, each monad's intrinsic properties can be read off of its relational properties, and each monad is therefore a mirror of the universe.

claim: Different monads provide different perspectives on the universe like observers of a town
text: Different monads provide different perspectives on the universe like observers of a town
quote: And just as a town appears differently to differently situated observers, so there are as many reflections of the universe as there are monads.

claim: God maximized both variety and order by making monads varied and prohibiting direct interaction
text: God maximized both variety and order by making monads varied and prohibiting direct interaction
quote: In this way, there is a maximum of variety in the universe, as well as a maximum of order. The fewer the differences between the monads in a given universe, the more those monads must interact with one another if that universe is to be internally differentiated. But the more they interact, the less orderly that universe is. By making monads as varied as possible, and by so pre-arranging their mutual relations as to reflect those differences, while prohibiting actual interactions from taking place, God endowed our universe with a maximum of variety and a maximum of order.

claim: This theory is the only one that does God justice and cannot be refuted
text: This theory is the only one that does God justice and cannot be refuted
quote: This theory, which I have rigorously proved, is the only one that does God justice. Even Bayle, who criticized it, saying that I had attributed too much to God, could not find any reason to reject it.

claim: Each monad reflects the universe with perspectival accuracy based on proximity and size
text: Each monad reflects the universe with perspectival accuracy based on proximity and size
quote: The condition of any given monad reflects that of the entire universe. The more internally differentiated a given monad is, the more accurate a mirror it is of the universe. Each monad reflects what is close more accurately than it reflects what is far, and it more accurately reflects what is large than it does what is small. This is because each monad is a picture, and it is inherent in the nature of pictorial representation that it be perspectival.

claim: No empty space means everything affects everything else; monads differ in clarity not information
text: No empty space means everything affects everything else; monads differ in clarity not information
quote: Because there is no such thing as empty space, there is nothing in the universe whose changes are not without an effect on everything else. If there were empty space, this would not be so, but there isn't, so it is. Thus each monad contains within itself a complete record of everything that happens in the universe. Thus, monads vary not in respect of the information that they bear, but in respect of how clearly they bear it.

claim: Monads represent their assigned bodies most clearly as entelechies
text: Monads represent their assigned bodies most clearly as entelechies
quote: And although each monad represents the whole universe, it represents the body assigned to it---the one of which it is the entelechy---more clearly than it represents others. And just as that body reflects the whole universe through its interconnections with other monads, so that soul represents the whole universe by representing that body.

claim: A living thing is a body with a monad-soul that has memory
text: A living thing is a body with a monad-soul that has memory
quote: A body that has a monad as its soul, taken in conjunction with that monad, is what we call a living thing. And we call a body a living thing if the monad that animates it is itself a soul, meaning that it is a mind that has memory.

claim: Animal bodies are highly organized because they mirror the orderly universe
text: Animal bodies are highly organized because they mirror the orderly universe
quote: Any given animal's body is highly organized, the reason being: 1. The universe is regulated in a perfectly orderly manner. 2. Each monad mirrors the universe in its own way. 3. The representing monad must be orderly to the extent that it is a good picture of the universe. 4. The body that it represents must to that extent itself be orderly.

claim: Every living thing is a divine automaton with parts that reflect its organization
text: Every living thing is a divine automaton with parts that reflect its organization
quote: Thus, every living thing is a kind of divine automaton. And whereas the constituents of an artificial automaton are not themselves artifices, and are therefore not reflective of that automaton's mode of organization, there is no part of an animal that does not itself partake of that animal's mode of organization.

claim: Infinite subdivision makes each unit of matter autonomous and reflective
text: Infinite subdivision makes each unit of matter autonomous and reflective
quote: And this is possible because each unit of matter not only can be, but is subdivided without end. And for this reason, each is autonomous, being its own source of motion and vitality, and not having, like a cog in a man-machine, to await an impulse from some other body. It is only because there is no end to these subdivisions that any given part of the universe is able to be a reflection of the rest.

claim: There is a world of living creatures within the smallest fragment of matter
text: There is a world of living creatures within the smallest fragment of matter
quote: It follows that there is a world of animals---of living things and souls, of entelechies and minds---within the smallest fragment of matter.

claim: Every particle contains infinite nested worlds of living creatures
text: Every particle contains infinite nested worlds of living creatures
quote: Every particle is a pond of full of living creatures, and every particle within each such creature, yet another such pond.

claim: Non-animal matter still contains animals too small to see
text: Non-animal matter still contains animals too small to see
quote: And although the earth and air separating animals are not themselves animals, they do yet contain animals, albeit ones too small for us to see in most cases.

claim: Nothing is truly dead or chaotic in the universe; apparent confusion is perceptual
text: Nothing is truly dead or chaotic in the universe; apparent confusion is perceptual
quote: There is therefore nothing dead or barren in the universe; nothing chaotic or confused, except in appearance. For example, if you look at a pond teeming with fish from a certain distance, you will see various motions on the part of fish but will not able to pick out any individual fish. You will therefore see these motions as confused, but it is not the motions themselves that are confused, but rather your perception of them.

claim: Every living body has a dominant soul while its parts contain other animals with souls
text: Every living body has a dominant soul while its parts contain other animals with souls
quote: It follows that every living body has a dominant entelechy or soul, which in the case of animals is itself an entelechy or soul. And each part of an animal is teeming with animals, each which itself has a soul.

claim: Bodies and souls are in constant flux with souls entering and leaving
text: Bodies and souls are in constant flux with souls entering and leaving
quote: If a body has a soul, it does not have that soul forever. Bodies are in constant flux, and souls therefore enter and leave them.

claim: Souls change bodies gradually and never lose all organs instantly
text: Souls change bodies gradually and never lose all organs instantly
quote: Thus, the soul changes its body only gradually, and no soul is ever instantly stripped of its bodily organs. So animals change form, but souls do not travel between them, as between distinct empty vessells.

claim: Birth and death are rapid development and decline, not creation and annihilation
text: Birth and death are rapid development and decline, not creation and annihilation
quote: Another consequence is that life never comes into existence ex nihilo nor completely goes out of existence. What we call conception is simply unusually rapid development, and what we call death is unusually negative development.

claim: Apparent spontaneous generation actually involves undetectable seeds or spores
text: Apparent spontaneous generation actually involves undetectable seeds or spores
quote: It used to be thought that animals came from nothing. We now know this to be false. Wherever there seems to be a case of spontaneous generation, there was in a fact a seed or spore, too small for us to detect, from which the animal in question developed. It follows that conception and death are not creation and annihilation, respectively, but are rather unusually rapid and involved forms of development and enfeeblement.

claim: Tiny animals can become larger through spermatic conception
text: Tiny animals can become larger through spermatic conception
quote: These days we are discovering that tiny animals that could become larger animals do so through a process of 'spermatic conception.' Most animals that can do so do not, it being a select few that make that transition.

claim: Animals have no beginning or end, consistent with no creation or annihilation
text: Animals have no beginning or end, consistent with no creation or annihilation
quote: But this is only half the story. An animal that has no way of starting also has no way of ending. These zoological discoveries of ours are therefore consistent with what we know a priori, that there is neither creation nor annihilation.

claim: Both souls and animals are indestructible though mechanisms may end
text: Both souls and animals are indestructible though mechanisms may end
quote: So not only is the soul indestructible, so too is the animal itself, though its particular mechanism may come to an end, and either throw off or take on organic coating.

claim: Mind-body harmony results from pre-established harmony without direct interaction
text: Mind-body harmony results from pre-established harmony without direct interaction
quote: The conformity of mind and body to one another is a consequence of the pre-established harmony discussed earlier. Mind and body do not interact, but mind reflects body and body reflects the universe. Hence the appearance of interaction.

claim: Animate and inanimate body behavior harmonizes despite different causal types
text: Animate and inanimate body behavior harmonizes despite different causal types
quote: For this very reason, the behavior of animate bodies harmonizes with that of inanimate bodies, even though the former is driven by final causes and the latter by efficient causes.

claim: Against Descartes: minds cannot redirect motions without violating conservation laws
text: Against Descartes: minds cannot redirect motions without violating conservation laws
quote: Descartes was aware that the total amount of energy in the universe remains the same. From this he inferred that minds could not cause bodies to move, but he did believe that minds could redirect existing motions. We now know this this too would violate the conservation-principle in question, and had Descartes known this, he would have opted for my system.

claim: Leibniz's system allows behavior to be both physically and psychologically caused
text: Leibniz's system allows behavior to be both physically and psychologically caused
quote: Our system is consistent with the supposition that the movements of an animal's body have strictly physical causes, and it is also consistent with the supposition that they have psychological causes. Our system therefore explains how it is that strictly physics-governed behavior can also be reason-governed.

claim: All souls can feel but only some can reason; none are created or destroyed
text: All souls can feel but only some can reason; none are created or destroyed
quote: No living soul is created and no living soul is destroyed. But whereas all living souls can feel, only some can reason.

claim: Rational souls resemble God and enter into community with Him
text: Rational souls resemble God and enter into community with Him
quote: A given soul resembles God to the extent that it is rational. On this basis, God enters into community with his subjects, relating to them not just as an inventor relates to his machines, but also a prince relates to his subjects and as a father relates to his children.

claim: The totality of monads constitutes the City of God, the most perfect kingdom
text: The totality of monads constitutes the City of God, the most perfect kingdom
quote: It follows that the totality of monads is the City of God, this being the most perfect kingdom imaginable.

claim: The City of God is a moral world within the natural world
text: The City of God is a moral world within the natural world
quote: This City of God is a moral world within the natural world.

claim: Efficient and final causes align as do Nature and Grace realms
text: Efficient and final causes align as do Nature and Grace realms
quote: Just as efficient causes align with final causes, so too, in this City of God, does the natural realm align with the Realm of Grace, and so therewith are the deeds of God as Designer brought into coincidence with those of God as Divine Monarch.

claim: Divine Moral Law requires physical events through Nature-Grace coincidence
text: Divine Moral Law requires physical events through Nature-Grace coincidence
quote: Divine Moral Law requires that there be events of a purely physical or natural variety, and this is indeed possible, owing to coincidence of the Realm of Nature with the City of God.

claim: Evil actions bring their own punishment and good deeds their own reward
text: Evil actions bring their own punishment and good deeds their own reward
quote: Owing to this same coincidence, evil actions bring their own punishment and good deeds lead to their own reward.

claim: We live in a maximally good world where virtue and vice receive due consequences
text: We live in a maximally good world where virtue and vice receive due consequences
quote: We therefore live in a maximally good world, in which virtue is duly rewarded and vice duly punished, and it is only because we are ignorant, and do not see reality clearly, that things seem to us to be otherwise.

claim: There are contradictions in the Monadology itself that this work reflects
text: There are contradictions in the Monadology itself that this work reflects
quote: There are contradictions in the following work, for example, in section it is said that monads cannot change, and in section 11 it is said that they can change. But these contradictions are present in the Monadology itself, and they are present in this work only because the present work is an elucidation of the Monadology.
